Question:
Comparison test:

Could someone explain to me the general approach to the comparison test. I find it relatively hard to find a function that works to prove whether something is convergent or divergent.

Also how can we tell if we should be looking for a larger or smaller comparison function (especially in a faster way for timed assessments)?
Answer:
It's hard to give advice that works in general, but here are a few useful facts.

Inequalities (assuming $$a,b\in\mathbb{R}$$ and that $$a,b > 0$$)

  • $$a
  • $$a < ab$$
  • $$a > a-b$$
  • $$a < \frac{a}{b}$$
  • $$ a > a^b$$ when $$a < 1$$ and $$a < a^b$$ when $$a>1$$.

More useful, suppose we have a function $$f$$ which we know has an upper bound, call it $$M$$. Then

  • $$a+f(x)\le a+M$$
  • $$af(x)\le aM$$

If we instead have that the lower bound of the function is $$L$$, then

  • $$a+L\le a+f(x)$$
  • $$aL \le af(x)$$

It's hard to give advice that works in general, but here are a few useful facts.

Inequalities (assuming $$a,b\in\mathbb{R}$$ and that $$a,b > 0$$)

  • $$a
  • $$a < ab$$
  • $$a > a-b$$
  • $$a < \frac{a}{b}$$
  • $$ a > a^b$$ when $$a < 1$$ and $$a < a^b$$ when $$a>1$$.

More useful, suppose we have a function $$f$$ which we know has an upper bound, call it $$M$$. Then

  • $$a+f(x)\le a+M$$
  • $$af(x)\le aM$$

If we instead have that the lower bound of the function is $$L$$, then

  • $$a+L\le a+f(x)$$
  • $$aL \le af(x)$$

Question:
Situations with "infinity" operations:

I remember in lecture section 0103 where Professor Mandelis and Karmianpour said that we can't treat infinities as "numbers". They said that if anything evaluates to "infinity" in an expression then it's automatically divergent at least in the scope of our course. When I was doing this question then, I had the expression (lim t --> + inf) ln(x^2 + 1) (Evaluated from -t and t). Do I automatically state that it's divergent then, even though algebraically the ln terms can be "subtracted" out to 0?
Answer:
yes. that is exactly what you do. if at least one of your limits is undefined, it's over.

additionally you should note for the same reason that vertical asymptotes are also considered divergent. if the function had an asymptote at $$x=a$$. that makes the integral over any interval containing $$a$$ divergent as well. yes. that is exactly what you do. if at least one of your limits is undefined, it's over.

additionally you should note for the same reason and for this particular question that vertical asymptotes are also considered divergent. this function has an asymptote at $$x=-1$$. that makes the integral over any interval containing $$-1$$, including this one, divergent as well.

Assignment 1 Solutions - Q3 (a):

Answer:
I believe it should say $$e^x + x^2\ge e^x+1$$ in the 2nd line of the solution.

They skipped a step between the 2nd and 3rd line: $$e^x+x^2\ge e^x+1 \implies \frac{1}{e^x+x^2}\le \frac{1}{e^x+1}$$, where taking the inverse is justified because $$e^x+1$$ and $$e^x+x^2$$ are greater than $$0$$ and the inverse function is decreasing on $$(0,\infty)$$. Moreover, we know that $$e^x>0$$ for all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$ so we can multiply both sides of the inequality by $$e^x$$ to get to the 3rd line.

I believe it should say $$e^x + x^2\ge e^x+1$$ in the 2nd line of the solution.

Ils ont sauté un étape entre le 2e et 3e ligne : $$e^x+x^2\ge e^x+1 \implies \frac{1}{e^x+x^2}\le \frac{1}{e^x+1}$$, où prenant l'inverse est justifié parce que $$e^x+1$$ et $$e^x+x^2$$ sont plus grand que $$0$$ et la fonction inverse est décroissante sur $$]0,\infty[$$. De plus on sait que $$e^x>0$$ pour tout $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$ donc on peut multiplier les deux côtés d'inégalité pour arriver à la 3e ligne.

I believe it should say e^x + x^2 >= e^x + 1 in the 2nd line of the solution

Question:
visualizing functions:

i often have trouble visualizing composite functions/product of functions without the use of desmos: does anyone have any advice on how to do this?

for example: sin(x^2), or (x^2)cosx, or (e^x)sinx
Answer:
for a lot of functions (and specifically the ones you've listed), you can use the ideas of "horizontal stretch and compression" that you learned in high school.

for example, in $$\sin{(x^2)}$$, you can remodel this as $$\sin{(ax)}$$ with some $$a$$ for which $$x^2=ax$$, meaning it's always growing. so you can consider this a "horizontal compression" of the function that continues to grow larger, and of course, that's what it looks like (also note that there's a reflection in the y-axis when $$x$$ changes sign).

the same thing applies for vertical compression. for $$x^2\cos{(x)}$$ you have a scaling factor of $$a$$ on $$ax\cos{(x)}$$ that continuously grows. so you can expect a vertical stretch which also grows (again, there's a reflection in the x-axis when $$x$$ changes sign). the same applies to $$e^x\sin{(x)}$$, although the function obviously looks much different than $$x^2$$, so I'll leave that up to you to consider.

when it comes to addition of functions it gets more complicated. in these cases you probably want to find the critical points, intercepts etc.

the same thing applies for vertical compression. for $$x^2\cos{(x)}$$ you have a scaling factor of $$a$$ on $$ax\cos{(x)}$$ that continuously grows. so you can expect a vertical stretch which also grows (again, there's a reflection in the x-axis when $$x$$ changes sign). the same applies to $$e^x\sin{(x)}$$ (this does not reflect!)

Question:
2019 midterm 1 q7 a):

for a question like this, is it enough to say: "the derivative of the integrand is positive on the interval of integration, which means the integral is concave up, so I would use the midpoint rule as it underestimates functions that are concave up"? or does the fact that midpoint rule underestimates concave up functions need to be justified as well?
Answer:
The function is not actually concave up throughout the entirety of that interval. If you graph the second derivative of the function it becomes negative at a certain point meaning that the function switches from concave up to concave down somewhere over the interval. I said I'd use the Left hand approximation just because after the switch in concavity I don't think you'd be able to guarantee that using a midpoint or trapezoid approximation would guarantee an underestimate. 
The derivative of the integrand would give you whether your function is increasing or decreasing. Think right and left endpoint for this question.

Question:
Term Test 1 2019 - Question 9 b):

Can someone please provide their procedure for part b)? I understood how to do the other parts of #9 but not this one (but I've attached part a) for context). Thank you
Answer:
When it looks like there's only one function and we have to use integration by parts, we can think of the integrand as $$1\cdot f(x)$$, and we integrate $$1$$ because it's easier. In this question :

$$\displaystyle \int\sqrt{1-x^2}\,dx=\int 1\cdot\sqrt{1-x^2}=x\sqrt{1-x^2}-\int x\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)'\,dx$$

Quand il semble qu'il y a seulement une fonction est on doit utiliser l'intégration par parties, on peut penser de l'intégrande comme $$1\cdot f(x)$$ est intégrer $$1$$ parce que c'est plus facile. Dans cette question :

$$\displaystyle \int\sqrt{1-x^2}\,dx=\int 1\cdot\sqrt{1-x^2}=x\sqrt{1-x^2}-\int x\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)'\,dx$$

Question:
2021 final q2:

for a), i said it's false because the bottom only converges for s>1, not s>0. but I don't know if you can just split an integral like that and say that if one part of the function diverges, then an integral containing the product of that function and another function diverges. 

i also tried providing a counterexample but it didn't go well (I don't know if I evaluated the integral correctly + it converged)
Answer:
<md>For $$x>1$$, $$\frac{e^{-sx}}{x^s}=\frac{1}{x^se^{sx}}<\frac{1}{e^{sx}}$$, the integral of which from 1 to infinity converges for all $$s>0$$.

The inequality is because $$x^s>1$$ for $$x>1$$ and $$s>0$$.</md>
<md>For $$x>1$$, $$\frac{e^{-sx}}{x^s}=\frac{1}{x^se^{sx}}<\frac{1}{e^{sx}}$$, the integral of which from 1 to infinity converges for all $$s>0$$.</md>
<md>For $$x>1$$, $$\frac{e^{-sx}}{x^s}=\frac{1}{x^se^{sx}}<\frac{1}{e^{sx}}$$, the integral of which from 0 to infinity converges for all $$s>0$$.</md>

Question:
Tut 5 is not available:

Hello, the tutorial for this week is not available, considering some students have their tutorial tomorrow can it be released now?

2023 Midterm 4 a):

with different methods, this integral evaluated to different results. If you did trig sub you get answer = pi, if you split fractions you get infinity - infinity midway which is indeterminant.

the online calculator evaluated that integral to pi, but also said it is divergent due to Cauchy principal value which I could not find in any course material, please help
Answer:
<md>You need to understand that the answer in 4(a) and (b) are not the same. The value that 4(a) is asking for is called the _Cauchy Principal Value_, and is related to but **not the same** as the improper integral from $$-\infty$$ to $$\infty$$. A useful explanation of why this is the case can be found on this Math Stack Exchange post: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/637516/why-int-infty-infty-x-dx-neq-0

For 4(a), evaluating the indefinite integral $$\int\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx$$ gives $$\frac{1}{2}\ln(x^2+1)+\arctan x + C$$. Then, if you plug in the bounds and evaluate from $$-t$$ to $$t$$, you will get $$2\arctan t$$. Taking the limit as $$t\to\infty$$, you will get the answer of $$\pi$$. This value is called the _Cauchy Principle Value (PV)_.

**However**, for the second integral in 4(b) **which is not the same as 4(a)**, you **cannot** use the same method as you did in part (a). This integral diverges and the easiest way to show this is to see that $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx=\int_{-\infty}^{0}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx$$ and seeing that both terms diverge when evaluated using the antiderivative.

Tl;dr: $$\lim\limits_{t\to\infty}\int_{-t}^{t}f(x)\ dx \neq \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(x)\ dx \equiv \lim\limits_{a\to-\infty}\lim\limits_{b\to\infty}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\ dx$$.</md>

This value is called the _Cauchy Principle Value (PV)_.

**However**, for the second integral in 4(b) **(which is not the same as 4(a))**, you **cannot** use the same method as you did in part (a). This integral diverges and the easiest way to show this is to see that $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx=\int_{-\infty}^{0}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx$$ and seeing that both terms diverge when evaluated using the antiderivative.

TL;DR: $$\lim\limits_{t\to\infty}\int_{-t}^{t}f(x)\ dx \neq \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(x)\ dx \equiv \lim\limits_{a\to-\infty}\lim\limits_{b\to\infty}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\ dx$$.</md>

Question: TUT3 Q3: Hey everyone, just curious if doing a limit comparison to 2/sqrt(x) is also sufficient here. The solution decides to use a lower bound (cos(1)/sqrt(x)) instead of the upper bound which I am suggesting. I feel that the upper bound is more useful as it can prove convergence as well. Let me know if that makes sense...
Answer:
there is nothing that proves convergence "as well." if an upper bound is divergent, then the behavior of functions beneath it is indeterminate. likewise, if a lower bound is convergent, the behavior for functions above it is indeterminate. you can only draw conclusions from the other 2/4 cases.
there is nothing that proves convergence "as well." if an upper bound is divergent, then the behavior of the function beneath it is indeterminate. likewise, if a lower bound is convergent, the behavior for functions above is is indeterminate. you can only draw conclusions from the other 2/4 cases.

Answer:
For Test 2 Q1, notice that the series looks like a Riemann sum. Try to convert it into a definite integral. **SPOILERS AHEAD** ... Note that the sum can be written as $$\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\sqrt{1-(\frac{i}{n})^2}\ \frac{1}{n}$$. The $$\frac{i}{n}$$ term looks a lot like our $$x_i$$'s and the $$\frac{1}{n}=Δx$$ term tells us that the length of the interval is 1. Using the fact that $$x_i=a+iΔx$$ for a right-endpoint Riemann sum it is not hard to see that our bounds of integration is from 0 to 1. Thus, our definite integral is $$\int_0^1 \sqrt{1-x^2}\ dx$$, which is the area of the quarter circle of radius one centered at the origin. Thus, the value we are looking for is $$\frac{\pi}{4}$$.
Alternatively, you could use trig sub to compute this integral but since this question is literally only worth 2 marks, I wouldn't waste time doing that. Question: Error Riemann: Can someone explain about 2 digit accuracy
Answer: This is another way of saying the absolute value of the error must be less than $$0.01$$ (using the definition at https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3394567). This is another way of saying the absolute value of the error must be less than $$0.005$$ (otherwise we get an incorrect value by rounding).

Question:
2023 Midterm Part A question 2 and 3:

Has anyone solved those two questions? I have been stuck on those two for 1 hour. Help!!!!!!!!!

Also, will the solution for the 2023 midterm one be posted like Calc 1?
Answer:
Question Nº2 is about approximation errors of an integral; you have to use the rules you learned in class (let $$I$$ be the true value of $$\int f(x)\,dx$$):

  • $$L_n\le I\le R_n$$ if $$f$$ is increasing on the integration interval (the reverse if $$f$$ is decreasing)
  • $$M_n\le I\le T_n$$ if $$f$$ is convex on the integration interval (the reverse if $$f$$ is concave).

We also have error bounds, which you can find in the A4 slideshow (on Quercus).

Question Nº3 is also about approximation errors, so use the $$R_n$$ error bound and solve for $$n$$.

Question Nº2 is about approximation errors of an integral; you have to use the rules you learned in class (soit $$I$$ le vrai valeur de $$\int f(x)\,dx$$):

  • $$L_n\le I\le R_n$$ si $$f$$ est croissante sur l'intervalle d'intégration (le revers si $$f$$ est décroissante)
  • $$M_n\le I\le T_n$$ si $$f$$ est convexe sur l'intervalle d'intégration (le revers si $$f$$ est concave

On a aussi des bornes d'erreur que vous pouvez trouver dans le slideshow A4 (sur Quercus).

Question Nº3 s'agit aussi d'erreurs d'approximation, il faut utiliser le borne d'erreur de $$R_n$$ et résoudre pour $$n$$.

Question: 2019 midterm q4: Is this C or D??
Answer:
You can't have discontinuities in the integration interval, so you have to separate the integral where they are. We can deduce that $$\frac{1}{\sin(x)}$$ is discontinuous when $$x\in\left\{t\in\mathbb{Z} : \pi|n\right\}$$. In the interval $$[-2,5]$$ there are two values where the function is discontinuous -- $$x=0$$ and $$x=\pi$$ -- so the integral must be separated there.

Furthermore, you may have at most one discontinuous bound in an integral.

You can't have discontinuities in the integration interval, so you have to separate the integral where they are. We can deduce that $$\frac{1}{\sin(x)}$$ is discontinuous when $$x\in\left\{t\in\mathbb{Z} : \pi|n\right\}$$. In the interval $$[-2,5]$$ there are two values where the function is discontinuous -- $$x=0$$ and $$x=\pi$$ -- so the integral must be separated there.

Furthermore, you must only have one discontinuous bound in an integral.

You can't have discontinuities in the integration interval, so you have to separate the integral where they are. We can deduce that $$\frac{1}{\sin(x)}$$ is discontinuous when $$x\in\left\{t\in\mathbb{Z} : \pi|n\right\}$$. In the interval $$[-2,5]$$ there are two values where the function is discontinuous -- $$x=0$$ and $$x=\pi$$ -- so the integral must be separated there.

Question:
2019 Midterm Questions:

How would I approach this question?

Given the initial values, Y' =0, but how do I determine if it's a max or min?
Answer:
Question 3 is about the length of an arc, not the area under a curve, so we can eliminate option A because it doesn't become more precise when we leave $$n\to\infty$$ (it remains constant, but the length of each arc is different). Also, we want a simple shape, so we don't use C or D. The only option left is B.

In question 5, the last three options are linked to the second derivative. Option E is obvious (inflection point), and for options C and D we can determine whether a critical point is a maximum or minimum by finding the convexity there (if convex it's a minimum and if concave it's a maximum).

Question:
Did we have to use the cooling law in question 2, HW2?:

In the second HW2 question, we were given two differential equations:

(1) $$T'(t)=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)$$

(2) $$T'(t)=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)+H(t)$$.

The first is Newton's cooling law, which describes only the cooling rate. If there are no other sources of heat or cooling it equals the net change, but in the question we have an external source: the radiator $$H(t)$$. Because of this, I assumed we had to ignore the first equation and used only the second.

I assumed the question asked us to find $$H(t)$$ where $$\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)+H(t)$$ would have equilibrium when $$T=20$$, so I wrote the equation $$0=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-20\right)+H(t)$$ and then arrived at $$H(t)=\frac{40}{3}-\frac{8}{9}t$$ (since $$A(t)=\frac{4}{3}$$).

So, was the first equation useless?
Answer: The first equation is not too necessary, yeah. It's there to show how we got to the second equation/relate it to an equation you know.

Question: 2019 midterm 9(b): How should I approach this question(9b)?
Answer:
We have the rule of thumb that for something of the form $$\sqrt{a^2 - x^2}$$ we might want to substitute $$x = a \sin(\theta)$$. After we do this substitution, we can use the $$1- \sin^2 = \cos^2$$ rule and integrate $$\cos^2$$ by parts if we treat it as just $$\cos$$ times $$\cos$$. (Though, if you know all your double angle identities, this isn't the only way to do it)

$$\sqrt{1-f^2(t)}f'(t)$$

$$\sqrt{g^2(t)}f'(t)$$

$$g(t)*f'(t)$$

$$f'(t)=g(t)$$

$$g^2(t) = RHS$$

Question:
2023 Midterm I Q2.c):

Hello,

How should I approach doing q2.c) from the 2023 past Midterm I? 

I can do it with a Riemann sum but the question says compute, not approximate.
Answer:
You can use integration by substitution and then decomposition into simple elements: let $$u=f(x)$$ then $$du=f'(x)\,dx$$, note that $$u\to 0$$ when $$x\to 1$$ and that $$u\to 1$$ when $$x\to 3$$, so the integral equals $$\displaystyle \int_0^1 \frac{7u+11}{(u+1)(2u+4)}\,du$$ and you can evaluate it using the graph.
You can use integration by substitution and then decomposition into simple elements: let $$u=f(x)$$ then $$du=f'(x)\,dx$$, note that $$u\to 0$$ when $$x\to 1$$ and that $$u\to 1$$ when $$x\to 3$$, so the integral equals $$\displaystyle \int_0^3 \frac{7u+11}{(u+1)(2u+4)}\,du$$ and you can evaluate it using the graph.
You can use integration by substitution and then decomposition into simple elements: either $$u=f(x)$$ or $$du=f'(x)\,dx$$, note that $$u\to 0$$ when $$x\to 1$$ and that $$u\to 1$$ when $$x\to 3$$, so the integral equals $$\displaystyle \int_0^3 \frac{7u+11}{(u+1)(2u+4)}\,du$$ and you can evaluate it using the graph.

Question:
Textbook Question 177-4.4:

Two monkeys are placed on an island. After 5 years there are 8 monkeys and the capacity of the island is 25. When does the population of monkeys reach 16 monkeys?

How do I approach this question? I know y(0)=2 and y(5)=8 and the lim(y) as t--> infinity is 25. Not sure what to do with this information tho

Looking online I see a "logistic growth equation", am I meant to just memorize that or is there a more intuitive way to do it
Answer:
(the growth equation as given by the textbook)

There's not really a more intuitive way than this. The textbook attempts to describe the intuition behind the equation in the next paragraph, though. 

Hi, 

This may not be the exact answer you want, but the logistic equation you aim to memorize can be derived from looking at birth rates (B) and death rates (D) for a given population (P), in addition to some constant of proportionality k over time T

In general, the population dP = k (B*P*dT - D*P*dT).  --> dP/dT = kP(B-D). The logistic equation is derived by grouping some constants together and giving these groupings meanings based on their physical meanings. I guess in this case you would need to memorize the logistic equation given that the question uses terms like 'capacity' which I think is code for M in the logistic equation dP/dT= kP (M-P). In other cases when given birth and death rates, it may serve to start from scratch (without the logistic equation)

Question: 2019 Midterm q6: Can anyone explain how to know if the separable ODE never finds solution? I thought it never finds a solution since y cannot be 0 but I’m not totally sure.
Answer:
You're right that y cannot be zero, and that is the solution that we find by using the separable method. So, this is a case where the method does not find a solution. But of course, we've seen cases in class where it does. Thus, we say B, sometimes finds a solution.

Also, a good way to show that we don't find a solution is, after we separate and integrate, we have $$y = \frac{-1}{x + c}$$ which means $$0 = \frac{-1}{0 + c}$$ which is of course impossible, so no c exists, so no solution exists

Question: 2023 part c 4b: For this question, wouldn't the function converge if I received a value for the integral that is not infinity? I've seen elsewhere that it diverges, so if someone could explain this to me, that would be great.
Answer:
Where did you hear that it diverges? 

The limit you received in question 4a is different to this one in 4b -- the first is the Cauchy Principal Value and the second is the normal improper integral. The goal of the former is to define some improper integrals that are otherwise undefined, so it is possible that a principal value will exist when an improper integral does not.

Question:
MidTermI- logistics equations:

Is the logistics equation be in the MidTermI?

This appeared in the WebWork and was not mentioned in either lectures or PCE. Are we expected to self-teach ourselves this topic?

Question:
Separation vs Integrating factors:

For the after-class practice, can someone show how separation of variables yield the same result? When I do separation of variables, I get something different.
Answer:
Without your work I can't tell you where you went wrong, but I present my solution:

$$\displaystyle y'=-e^ty \Rightarrow \frac{y'}{y}=e^t \Rightarrow \int\frac{1}{y}\,dy=-\int e^t\,dt \Rightarrow \ln|y|=-e^t+C_0$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow |y|=e^{-e^t+C_0}$$, soit $$C_1=e^{C_0}$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow y=C_1e^{-e^t}$$, en combinant la signe de valeur absolu avec $$C_1$$

Sans votre travail je ne peux pas vous dire où vous vous êtes trompés, mais je vous présente ma solution :

$$\displaystyle y'=-e^ty \Rightarrow \frac{y'}{y}=e^t \Rightarrow \int\frac{1}{y}\,dy=-\int e^t\,dt \Rightarrow \ln|y|=-e^t+C_0$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow |y|=e^{-e^t+C_0}$$, soit $$C_1=e^{C_0}$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow y=C_1e^{-e^t}$$, en combinant la signe de valeur absolu avec $$C_1$$

Question: 2017 Term Test 1 Q11: For Q11 part b from 2017 term test 1 I got the function 1/x sqrt(1-1/x^2). How do I prove this function diverges from 1 to infinity?
Answer:
Notice that the integral from 1 to infinity is the same as the integral from 1 to 2 and 2 to infinity

Note that from 2 to infinity, the square root thing is between 1 and root of a half, so that's a constant you can take out. Then 1/x diverges.

Question:
2023 question 1 c:

How do we go about solving this. I tried looking for the max value of the first derivative but that got me nowhere.
Answer:
What makes you say it got you nowhere? How did you try to find the maximum of it. If you look at the first derivative and it isn't clear what the maximum is, there are a couple things you can do. For one, you can find the second derivative, because the max of the first derivative will happen when the second derivative is zero.

or, in this case, since the first derivative is (tell me if you got something else because I might be wrong) $$−2e^{−sin^2(x)}cos(x)sin(x)$$ We can find the upper bound of the magnitude of each of these parts separately. So, $$|-2| \leq 2$$ and $$e^{-\sin^2(x)} \leq e$$ and $$|\sin(x)| \leq 1$$ and $$|\cos(x)| \leq 1$$, and we can take that together, though this will be a slightly less accurate bound

Question:
How did we arrive at this answer?:

In reference to question 14 and 15.
Answer:
We know that if we start at 1.5, we're going to approach 1, which will mean we go down. We also know that the derivative gets more negative as y increases, so it won't be one of the graphs that are more level at the beginning.

On the other hand, starting at 0.2, we know we're also going to go to 1, which means increasing. But, the derivative, when y = 0.2 will be 5(0.2)(0.8) whereas at y=0.5 it'll be faster at 5(0.5)(0.5). If she speed is lower at the beginning, then it'll have that flat part at the beginning as we see in C

Question:

$$\int f'(x)(2x + 2) = \int 2x f'(x) + 2 \int f'(x)$$

the average is the sum of $$n$$ y-values over $$n$$. to get all values linear interpolated between $$a$$ and $$b$$, you can do $$\sum_{i=1}^{n}f((b-a)\frac{i}{n}+a)$$. this is because $$\frac{i}{n}$$ is the "percentage" of the distance you've crossed, $$b-a$$ is the "distance" and $$a$$ is the "starting point." so you'll need to pick one that fits this form, which leaves two choices.

finally, we need to average all the values by dividing by $$n$$. $$\frac{i}{n}$$ doesn't make sense unless it was a riemann sum, so we need $$\frac{1}{n}$$.

Question:
Danger of division by 0:

But sometime, when we manipulate our ODE into standard form, we also create a scenario where the division of 0 may occur, and the found solution will be invalid at a point. How should we deal with this in the mid-term? Specifically what would be the approach if we have an invalid point of our solution?
Answer:
If you find a scenario where division by zero occurs from putting your equation into standard form, the division by zero wouldn't be dependent on y (because of the layout of standard form). So, this would mean there are some values of t where the ODE is invalid. 

So, in that case, if they ask when the ODE isn't valid, you talk about that. They probably won't give you an ODE and ask you to solve it as a trick question, though

Question:
Lec 4-1 Unfinished Questions:
Did anyone happen to finish off/complete these last two questions from lecture 4-1? If so could you please share your solution
Answer:
For level three, a piecewise function must be used because the rate of fluid loss is not constant. Specifically, during the first 100 minutes the expression for fluid volume is $$V(t)=50+t$$, but after 100 minutes it is $$V(t)=150$$ because that is the reservoir capacity (it cannot be exceeded). Moreover, after 100 minutes, the amount of fluid leaving the reservoir equals 3 L/min, not 2 L/min. So the initial value problem is

$$\displaystyle y'(t)=\begin{cases}30-\frac{2y(t)}{50+t} &t< 100\\ 30-\frac{3y(t)}{150} &t\ge 100\end{cases}$$

$$y(0)=100.$$

For part (b), just take the second branch. For part (c), note that the behavior of the first branch does not affect the behavior of the limit when $$t\to\infty$$, so only the second branch should be considered.

Question:
Lecture D1 question (complex #):

please look at the writing in red.
Answer:
Using Euler's formula with $$e^{(2-3i)t}$$, we calculate $$e^{2t}\cdot e^{-i(3t)}=e^{2t}\left(\cos(-3t)+i\sin(3t)\right)=e^{2t}\cos(3t)-ie^{2t}\sin(3t)$$. With the definitions of $$y_1(t)$$ and $$y_2(t)$$, we can write $$e^{(2-3i)t}=y_1(t)-iy_2(t)$$. Since $$e^{(2-3i)}t$$ is a linear combination of $$y_1(t)$$ and $$y_2(t)$$, it can be included in the general solution.

Regarding your second question, we know that both terms are equal to zero because we already know that $$z(t)$$ is a solution to the differential equation, so we have $$z''(t)-4z'(t)+13z(t)=0+0i$$. Using the method of equating coefficients, we deduce that both terms must be equal to zero.

Question:
PCE B1 question: In PCE B1, it states that s’’(t)= t^2 + 1 is a differential equation. 

Is it only a differential equation? Or can we consider it a second-order ordinary differential equation?
Answer:
It's still a second order differential equation simply because it includes the $$s''(t)$$ term.
It's still a second order ODE simply because it includes the $$s''(t)$$ term.
Any 2nd-order differential equation is also a differential equation.

Question:
Module B1 question: In the lecture given for module B1, it’s stated that when we find a solution to a first-order differential equation there is practically always a constant C in the solution. 

I’m unsure as to why this is the case.
Answer:
<md>If you take the derivative of a function with a constant term, that goes away. If you have to integrate that derivative, you don’t know what that constant is anymore. When you solve ODEs and have to integrate, you don’t know if the integral has a constant at the end or not, so you put C as a placeholder for some unknown constant.

$$\begin{gathered}\frac{d}{dx} x^{2}+1=2x\\ \int 2x\  dx=x^{2}+C\end{gathered}$$</md>

Question:
WeBWorK 6, Problem 9:

For this problem, I thought I was supposed to start using a general $$y_{p}(t) = f(t)g(t)$$, but I got stuck. Am I approaching the problem incorrectly?
Answer:
When solve for the characteristic equation, you get:

$$e^{rt}(r+9) = 0$$, which when solved yields:

$$r = ±3i$$, which is expressed in the form $$0±3i$$ where $$a=0$$ and $$b=3$$.

So, you know that your characteristic equation is: $$y_c = e^{0t}(c_1\cos{3t} + c_2\sin{3t}) = c_1\cos{3t} + c_2\sin{3t}$$.

This should have tipped you off initially that your particular solution cannot just be of the form $$y_p = k\sin{3t}$$, as that would equate to zero. Rather, you should be using something that when differentiated behaves very similar to it.

Try using a solution of the form $$y_p = kt\sin{3t}$$ and solving from there.

Question:
Do both y1 and y2 always solutions when we rewrite in terms of trigonometric function?:

Does it always have two solutions (y1, y2) or do we always have to check if both are solutions or only either one of them is a final solution?
Answer: The solution space of a second-order ODE is two-dimensional. You can always find two linearly independent solutions that make a basis for the space and whose span generates the entire general solution. In this case, $$y_1$$ and $$y_2$$ make up a basis.

Question: Webwork 6 Problem 9: How do we determine our initial guess for the particular solution? I'm honestly confused how to formulate it.
Answer:
There are two things to consider:
1) As you plug your guess function in the ODE new terms are generated by taking the derivatives. Hence the derivatives of the force function (the function on the right) should show up in the summands of the guess solution. 
2) If the terms of your guess function also appear in the complementary solution, then they can not serve as a particular solution. Typically, multiplying by a linear factor solves this issue.    Typically for a problem like this one your initial guess would be something of the form $$A\sin(kx)+B\cos(kx)$$.

Question:
PCE E1 Approximating Error Question:

How did we get the equation they said in the below when the function is e^x? I get the first part, but the third taylor polynomial doesnt make sense to me. Isnt it supposed to be in the form of f^n(a)/n! times (x-a)^n?
Answer: You're right that each term of the Taylor series is of the form $$\frac{f^{(n)}(x)}{n!}\left(x-a\right)^n$$. In this example we use $$a=0$$ (the approximation centers on $$x=0$$) and $$f(x)=e^x$$, so the 3rd term equals $$\frac{(\exp)'''(0)}{3! }\left(x-0\right)^3=\frac{\exp(0)}{3!}x^3=\frac{x^3}{3!}$$ because the derivative of $$\exp$$ is itself and $$\exp(0)=1$$.

Question:
Question about Characteristic polynomial in the method of undetermined coefficients:

I was wondering why we would ever even need to find the characteristic polynomial when doing the method of undetermined coefficients when all you need is to take the original equation and plug into its y values the formula that you are using to guess. 

e.g./ for y'' -4y' -5y = 5t^2 - 2t

all you do is just try y = At^2 + Bt + C (1)

then y' = 2at  + b

then y'' = 2a

and you just sub and solve for the a b and c values and then put that back into (1) and then you have your particular solution. 

is finding the characteristic polynomial and characteristic solution even necessary?
Answer:
Let's say you're given the ODE: $$y''-4y'-5y=3e^{5t}$$. Say you skip finding the complementary solution and directly guess $$y(t)=Ae^{5t}$$, you'll find that at the end you have $$0=3e^{5t}$$. Now you have to go back and complete the whole process again with $$y(t)=Ate^{5t}$$.

If you had found the characteristic equation first, you would have gotten:

$$r^2-4r-5=0 \to (r-5)(r-1)=0\to r=5, r=1$$. 

This makes your complementary solution $$c_1e^{5t}+c_2e^{t}$$. Now for some reason that I do not fully recall, because your original guess is actually part of the complementary solution, you should end up with the above invalid statement. But essentially, this is why we check the compementary solution regardless.

Question:

Answer:
This means that every element of the set $$\mathbb{C}$$ is an object of the form $$a+bi$$ where $$a,b$$ are arbitrary real numbers. And yes, $$\mathbb{C}$$ forms a two-dimensional vector space (a plane).
If you visualize $$1$$ and $$i$$ as two vectors, then $$\mathbb C$$ is the span of these two vectors.

Question: D3 textbook question 99: Hello! I'm having trouble with this question. I set up my differential equation to be 3/16 x'' + 24x = 8sin(4t) with x(0) = 1. However, I'm not sure how to solve this differential equation without x'(0)
Answer:
(I have no expertise with US customary units so I can't verify the accuracy of your equation, but I can tell you how to solve it.)

The differential equation $$\frac{3}{16}x''+24x=8\sin(4t)$$ is second-order, non-homogeneous and linear, so we can use the method of particular solutions.

Substituting $$y_p=k\sin(4t)$$ into the equation we get $$-3k\sin(4t)+24k\sin(4t)=8\sin(4t)$$, hence $$k=\frac{8}{21}$$ and $$y_p=\frac{8}{21}\sin(4t)$$.

Using the characteristic polynomial (let $$x=e^{kt}$$) we get the general solution, thus the final answer is the sum of the particular and characteristic solutions.

(I have no expertise with US customary units so I can't verify the accuracy of your equation, but I can tell you how to solve it.)

The differential equation $$\frac{3}{16}x''+24x=8\sin(4t)$$ is second-order, non-homogeneous and linear, so we can use the method of particular solutions.

Substituting $$y_p=k\sin(4t)$$ into the equation we get $$-3k\sin(4t)+24k\sin(4t)=8\sin(4t)$$, hence $$k=\frac{8}{21}$$ and $$y_p=\frac{8}{21}\sin(4t)$$.

Using the characteristic polynomial (let $$x=e^{kt}$$) we get $$\frac{3}{16}k^2+24=0$$, thus $$k=\pm8\sqrt2\cdot i$$ and $$y_c=C_1\cos(8\sqrt2 t)+C_2\sin(8\sqrt2 t)$$.

Question:
Calculus Studying Methods:

Hi this isn't necessarily related to any in-course items, but I didn't do as well on the first midterm as I had anticipated, and calculus happens to be one of my weaker subjects. 

I just wanted to use this platform to ask what study techniques I should use going forward that helped those who were initially struggling to improve, or to those who are already strong in this subject.

What I did to study for the first midterm was re-reading the in-class slideshows & doing those examples on my own, textbook questions, going over written homework and then doing past exams. Is there anything else I should be doing?
Answer:
I can't give you useful advice without the specific area that's causing you problems, but I will present some options depending on which part of math is the greatest struggle.

Calculation/Computation

If you find that you can set up equations but struggle to get the right answer, I can think of two additional practice methods (the only way to improve this is practice)

  1. Go backwards in a sense -- start with an answer and then generate a problem that produces the answer using the technique you struggle with. This gives you a sense of patterns that will emerge in constructed (exam) situations, but I only recommend this if you are already strong with the subject.
  2. Generate random problems -- if you really want to you can download the WebWork software to generate problem sets on your own: https://openwebwork.org/. Otherwise, just write down random equations that should be solvable with the desired technique and try to get an answer (using sites such as WolframAlpha to verify)

Theorem Application/Conceptual Questions

If you struggle to use theorems, I would suggest reading and working through the exercises contained in an introduction to proofs book/course. I will say this takes a lot of effort (it took me 6 months to get through a full course), but it is very good for developing your mathematical logic. Some books that I used that I found useful:

  • Proofs and Fundamentals -- A First Course in Abstract Mathematics (Ethan D. Bloch, Birkhäuser 2000)
  • Book of Proof (Richard Hammack, online http://www.people.vcu.edu/~rhammack/BookOfProof/)
  • Basic Analysis: Introduction to Real Analysis (Jiří Lebl, online https://www.jirka.org/ra/) -- This one is more advanced but if you feel comfortable with set theory already it's a good exercise

Word Problems

I would recommend doing physics textbook exercises that involve calculus (there are some in the ECE textbook). I don't really have much advice for this (d'habitude je lis et je travaille en français donc les questions qui comprennent l'interpretation des phrases causent des problèmes pour moi).

Question:
Midterm 1 (this year) - Part B 2a (ii):

For this question, what is the difference between expressing the final answer as an arccos term instead of an arctan term (as is given in the solutions document)? Looking forward to anyone's help on this!
Answer:
If your trig substitution involves $$\tan\theta$$, as it is the case for this question, your final answer will be in terms of arctan. If you have tried a different substitution that worked, please share your steps so we can comment on the form of the final answer. If your trig substitution involves $$\tan\theta$$, as it is the case for this question, your final answer will be in terms of arctan. If you have tried a different substitution that worked, please share your steps so we can comment on teh steps and teh form of the final answer. 

(Response to a comment) Your primitive is not exactly correct; taking the derivative we get $$\frac{x-1}{|x-1|(x^2-2x+10)}\ne\frac{1}{x^2-2x+10}$$ because the former is not defined at $$x=1$$, but the original function is defined there.

The error occurs because the substitution $$\theta(x)=\arccos\left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{(x-1)^2+9}}\right)$$ violates the hypothesis of the theorem that allows us to make a change of variables. Recall the full statement:

Suppose $$g:[a,b]\mapsto I$$ is a differentiable function with a continuous derivative, where $$I\subseteq\mathbb{R}$$ is an interval. Furthermore, suppose $$f:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ is continuous on $$I$$. Then $$\int_a^b (f\circ g)(x)\cdot g'(x)\,dx=\int_{g(a)}^{g(b)} f(u)\,du$$.

Note that $$\frac{d}{dx}\arccos\left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{(x-1)^2+9}}\right) = \frac{3(x-1)}{|x-1|\left((x-1)^2+9\right)}$$, a non-continuous function at $$x=1$$.

(Response to a comment) Your primitive is not exactly correct; taking the derivative we get $$\frac{x-1}{|x-1|(x^2-2x+10)}\ne\frac{1}{x^2-2x+10}$$ because the former is not defined at $$x=1$$, but the original function is defined there.

Question:
Second Order ODE behaviour (D3 PCE, D2 LEC): I am confused on what the graph of a second order solution is supposed to indicate? For example, is it supposed to indicate something for specific time points? What do the oscillations mean? How are we supposed to graph them?

Thanks for any help.
Answer:
Typically when we say graph of the solution, we mean a particular solution (note that there are infinitely many solutions to any ODE).

For the second-order ODE, in D1 and D2 we discussed everything that could happen in terms of the roots of the characteristic polynomial. We also discussed what the general solution looks like. In one of the cases, where the characteristic polynomial has no real roots, you will get a linear combination of sin and cos in the general solution. These are oscillating functions. That means your solution will oscillate.

Question:
Euler's Formula:

Hello, can someone explain how this works?

I thought in this example, we should have two e^(rts), one having +i and the other having -i, thus having TWO sets of cosine and sine. How did our profs "shrink" it into only one cosine and one sine?
Answer:
They combined the constants, starting with $$\alpha\exp\left(i\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)+\beta\exp\left(-i\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)$$, we can write $$\alpha\cos\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + \alpha\cdot i\sin\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + \beta\cos\left(-\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + \beta\cdot i\sin\left(\sqrt{-\frac{k}{m}}t\right)$$ by Euler's formula.

Since $$\sin(-\theta)=-\sin(\theta)$$ et $$\cos(-\theta)=\cos(\theta)$$ we can therefore write $$\cos\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)\left[\alpha+\beta\right] + \sin\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)\left[i\alpha-i\beta\right]$$. Let $$c_1=\alpha+\beta$$ and $$c_2=i\alpha+i\beta$$, therefore $$c_1\cos\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + c_2\sin\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)$$.

Question: PCE E1 question: What does it mean for a Taylor polynomial to “agree” with a function at a point?
Answer:
I think it is an informal way to say that the Taylor polynomial at that point will have the same value for each derivative as the function it is trying to model (depending on how many derivatives you want, which denotes the accuracy). 

In general, the Taylor polynomial will be more accurate around for example x=0 when it is set up to model the original function at x=0 when it has more derivatives. However, as you move away from that point, then your Taylor polynomial generally (and quickly) becomes a worse approximation.

Here is a video I found helpful for visualizing: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3d6DsjIBzJ4

Question:
Splitting integral question: if I wanted to integrate a function f(x) WRT to x along some interval [a,c], 

When can I safely split the integral, if at all?

Split the integral as in: IMG_6040_2024_02_29.jpeg
Answer:
Assuming $$f$$ is a continuous function, you can split it at any $$x\in(a,c)$$.
Adding to the student's solution, you can also confidently split an integral at a removable discontinuity. Once you have a vertical asymptote, then you should use improper integration.

Question:
D3 LEC103 Question 6:

The complementary soln. is 

and the particular is 

Would there ever be "shared solns", or perhaps more so "shared values" no matter what A, B, c1, and c2 are? My idea is that they are quasi periodical, so there might be same values given a same t. What would they mean? In my mind that would imply the "solution spaces" of the complementary and particular would overlap at some points, but then what would THAT mean? Alternatively, would the IVP "take over" here and ensure that such a thing never happens? OR another line of thinking I have is when solving for A and B, the ODE's nature itself would show that it is impossible for such "shared values"?
Answer:
The complementary solution is teh screenshot you included. However, the particular solution is not what appears in the screenshot. That gives you a general form for a guess for a particular solution. $$x_p$$ is then found by plugging in this guess into the ODE and finding A and B.

Any function in the general solution generates 0 when plugged into the left side of the ODE. Any particular solution solves the ODE with an external force. So these will never coincide. Geometrically, the space of complementary and particular solutions make parallel planes. 

The complementary solution is teh screenshot you included. However, the particular solution is not what appears in the screenshot. That gives you a general form for a guess for a particular solution. $$x_p$$ is then found by plugging in this guess into the ODE and finding A and B.

Question:
Webwork 7 Q2:

For the second part of question 2, shouldn't the answer be NO since critical damp approaches 0 when t goes to infinity but never reaches t axis?

Thank you!
Answer: If you use the optimization process to calculate the minimum and maximum on $$t\in[0,\infty)$$ you may find that the minimum is negative. Physically this means that the system initially overcompensates but dampens quickly afterwards.

Question: Question about E1: Hi for this example, how does the left side equal the right? How did (e^x)* c = e^c?
Answer: It is not multiplied by c, it is the value of the fourth derivative at point c. And the fourth derivative of e^x is e^x so f’’’’(c) = e^c.

Question:
Monday Strike: Does any of the TAs have information regarding the strike. An agreement between the cupe members and UofT hasn’t been reached as of now by the looks of it but does that mean the TAs will go on a strike or not?
I will appreciate a bit of clarification on the matter.
Answer:
Uodate: I can confirm that there will be no strike and the union secured a deal!



Generally, contract negotiations always go down to the wire. This means that even if there is a deal (in which case there won't be a strike), that deal will be reached in the last minutes. Negotiations are still ongoing and it is quite likely that they will continue until midnight. This also means that no one (literally no one, not even the president of the union or the president of the university) will know until shortly before midnight if there is a strike or not.

 

We very much understand that this is a stressful and anxious situation for students to be in. We sincerely wish we would know more, but unfortunately we (the professors) do not have any particular inside knowledge. Unfortunately, we know just as much (or as little) about this as you.

[Edit: Over writing all this, I forgot to answer the actual question. The poster you are sharing is about a protest that was advertised independent of the actual strike happening or not. The poster is not a confirmation of a strike.]

 

We recommend the following for all your classes:

  • Plan for the upcoming week under the assumption that there will NOT be a strike, i.e. assume that all lectures, all tutorials, all assessments etc. are running as usual, that there will be no new deadlines, no changes, no extensions.
  • Before heading out to class tomorrow morning, check your email inbox and the Quercus pages for all your courses for updates.
  • Even if a strike is happening, note that this does NOT necessarily mean that everything is cancelled. This depends a lot on individual situations. Unless you get an announcement that something is cancelled, assume that it is not cancelled.

Also, regarding the midnight deadline, note that in previous negotiation rounds this deadline was sometimes extended into the early morning, so we might need to wait longer than midnight (I vaguely recall a few years ago where it took until 4am or something). Furthermore, even if a strike is called at midnight, it's unlikely that there will be any clear announcements within the first hours (since we will - hopefully - be asleep by then). That's why I wouldn't recommend "hitting the refresh button nonstop at midnight in the hope of an update".

 

I think the most important thing at this moment is to be aware of two things:

  1. We are all humans and we will navigate this whole situation in a way where we help each other out. Everyone has their understandable causes and goals (students, TAs, professors, ...) but it's important to keep in mind that in the end, everyone is doing their best to act in good faith to make this learning experience here at U of T as good as possible, both in the short run, and in the long run.
  2. Sometimes, things in life are out of your control and the best is to try to not lose your mind (or your sleep) over this. It's easy to go down the spiral of "what if..." and "it's going to be so bad if ..." and so on.

I am by no means trying to dismiss your concerns, your anxiety, or your worries. I know and we know that - even without a possible strike looming - March is always a tough time at university since the term has been going on for so long and a lot of high stakes assessments are happening. We see that and hear that! I am just trying my best here to recommend taking your mind off of this whole thing and just wait until it happens (or not).

 

In my professional opinion, the best thing to do tonight (once you are done with your usual coursework of course) is to watch a few episodes of your favourite TV show, or to hang out with some friends, and get a good nights sleep. If someone is questioning you, tell them "my prof told me to watch TV/to hang out with my friends" :)

Question:
Webwork 8 Problem 6 factorial algebra:

Hi,

I was able to complete Q6 of Webwork 8 by guess and checking the factorial with my calculator. But, on an exam without a calculator, is there a way to algebraically solve an equation that has x! where x is to be found? 

Thanks
Answer: In general, solving $$\frac{1}{n!}\leq 1/100000$$ (or something similar) is quite tricky. But no worries, when we ask you to do Taylor polynomial/series stuff in a test, the questions are usually chosen so that you get there with guessing. It's usually handy to have the first few factorials easily accessible in memory, just to avoid spending time computing them by hand (I would say up to 5! or 6! can't hurt).

Question: Webwork 8 question 6: For this question, every odd derivative of cos(x) centered at 0, would equal 0 but to get 4 decimal places, you would need of degree 7 but that doesn't work because it equals to 0, so could someone explain this to me?
Answer:
If degree 6 is too low and degree 7 is the same as degree 6, then the minimum degree must be higher than 7

If you look at the remainder formula, $$ R_{n}(x) = f^{(n+1)}(c)/(n+1)!*(x-a)^{(n+1)} $$
It is concerned with the next degree after your minimum, if you're using it to calculate the reminder of cos(1) at degree 7 it would use degree 8. So if the error is less than 4 decimal places for degree 8, degree 7 is the minimum. 

Here the answer for degree 7 just happens to be the same as degree 6, however if you were to calculate the error at degree 6 it would be above 4 decimal places. 

TLDR: degree 6 would be the "true" answer but you can't verify it using the remainder formula. 
If degree 6 is too low and degree 7 is the same as degree 6, then the minimum degree must be higher than 7

If degree 6 is too low and degree 7 is the same as degree 6, then the minimum degree must be higher than 7

If you look at the remainder formula, $$ R(x) = f^{(n+1)}(c)/(n+1)!*(x-a)^{(n+1)} $$
 It is concerned with the next degree after your minimum, if you're using it to calculate  the reminder of cos(1) at degree 7 it would use degree 8. So if the error is less than 4 decimal places for degree 8, degree 7 is the minimum. 

Here the answer for degree 7 just happens to be the same as degree 6, however if you were to calculate the error at degree 6 it would be above 4 decimal places.

Question:
External Forces w/ Second-Order ODEs: Given a second-order ODE (e.g. a damped spring) with an external force, it is written as:

ay'' + by' + cy = f(t)

Is there a reason for this? I understand we obtain the homogenous equation using force balancing, but I don't understand how the external force is applied here. Does it oppose the other forces?
Answer:
The meaning of each term:

  • $$ay''$$ is the net force
  • $$by'$$ is the force that depends on the object's current speed
  • $$cy$$ is the force that depends on the object's current position
  • $$f(t)$$ is the force that is independent of the object -- it's an external force applied with a value unrelated to position or velocity, only to time.

Due to the definition of $$f(t)$$ it can either oppose or augment the other two forces, it depends on what exactly the external force is (since this is a fairly broad catch-all)

The meaning of each term:

  • $$ay''$$ is the net force
  • $$by'$$ is the force that depends on the object's current speed
  • $$cy$$ is the force that depends on the object's current position
  • $$f(t)$$ is the force that is independent of the object -- it's an external force applied with a value unrelated to position or velocity, only to time.

Student answer explains the salient points quite well. One of Netwon's law states that the net forces on an object can be related to it's acceleration as

$$\vec F_{net} = m \vec a$$. Since we know that acceleration is the second derivative of position, we can rewrite this as $$\vec F_{net} = m \frac{d^2 \vec s}{dt^2}$$, where $$\vec s$$ is the position. 

So if we find all the net forces (spring force, damping, gravity, etc.), we can set up an ODE like the student above explained.

Question: Relationship between quasi-period and period: For questions that indicate the quasiperiod of an oscillation, I read that this refers to the time taken for the system to go between two successive peaks of motion. Thus, do the quasiperiod and period have the same values for an oscillation?
Answer:
For a function $$f$$ to be periodic, we require that $$f(x+T) = f(x) $$ for all x in the function's domain.  Here, $$T$$ represents the period.

However, consider a function which we have discussed a lot in this course:

$$f(t) = e^{rt} \sin t$$

This function seems periodic in the sense that the time it takes to go from peak to peak is constant, but it fails to meet the definition of periodic above ($$f(x+T) \neq f(x) $$). We call this function quasi-periodic, and we can find the quasi period by finding the time between successive peaks. 

If we find the time between successive peaks for a $$\sin$$ function, it is $$2\pi$$, so it's 'quasi-periodic' with period $$2\pi$$. We also know that $$\sin(x+2\pi) = \sin(x)$$ for any x, so $$\sin$$ is periodic by the definition I laid out in the beginning.

For a function $$f$$ to be periodic, we require that $$f(x+T) = f(x) $$ for all x in the function's domain.  Here, $$T$$ represents the period.

However, consider a function which we have discussed a lot in this course:

$$f(t) = e^rt \sin t$$

This function seems periodic in the sense that the time it takes to go from peak to peak is constant, but it fails to meet the definition of periodic above ($$f(x+T) \neq f(x) $$). We call this function quasi-periodic, and we can find the quasi period by finding the time between successive peaks. 

If we find the time between successive peaks for a $$\sin$$ function, it is $$2\pi$$, so it's 'quasi-periodic' with period $$2\pi$$. We also know that $$\sin(x+2\pi) = \sin(x)$$ for any x, so $$\sin$$ is periodic by the definition I laid out in the beginning.

For a function $$f$$ to be periodic, we require that $$f(x+T) = f(x) $$ for all x in the function's domain.  Here, $$T$$ represents the period.

However, consider a function which we have discussed a lot in this course:

$$f(t) = e^rt \sin t$$

This function $$\emph{seems}$$ periodic in the sense that the time it takes to go from peak to peak is constant, but it fails to meet the definition of periodic above ($$f(x+T) \neq f(x) $$). We call this function quasi-periodic, and we can find the quasi period by finding the time between successive peaks. 

If we find the time between successive peaks for a $$\sin$$ function, it is $$2\pi$$, so it's 'quasi-periodic' with period $$2\pi$$. We also know that $$\sin(x+2\pi) = \sin(x)$$ for any x, so $$\sin$$ is periodic by the definition I laid out in the beginning.

Question:
Webwork Q4:

Hi,

I had a question about writing the Maclaurin series as a sum in webwork for the 4th question. I'm not sure how to format how we take the nth derivative each time of the function, how would I write it down, because the only way I am used to writing derivatives is using ' . 

thank you!
Answer:
For the functions given in the question, it is possible to calculate an explicit formula for the nth derivative of a function.

For example, if we have the function $$f(x)=\frac{1}{2x}$$, we can write the n-th derivative as $$f^{(n)}(x)=\frac{n!(-1)^n}{2x^{n+1}}$$ (I advise you to verify why this formula works).

You need to do something similar for your answer to question 4.

The best approach is to write the first 4 or 5 derivatives and then look for any pattern that merges. Then guess the $$n-$$th derivative based on your observation. Write your guess down and then cross-check it with the derivatives you already wrote. If it matches, use it to predict the next derivative.

For the functions in this question, you will see a pattern that makes it feasible to write the general $$n$$-th derivative.

Question: webwork 8 problem 6 (decimal places): Could somebody please explain to me how to approach this problem? I am so lost. I know that we should be using the error formula and that the error should be less than 0.0005, but I don't know how to actually solve for the min degree taylor polynomial. Thanks so much
Answer:
The remainder theorem for Taylor polynomials states that the remainder between a function and it's n'th Taylor polynomial centred for x in some interval centred at a is 

$$R_n(x) \leq \frac{|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|}{(n+1)!}|x-a|^{n+1}$$

... where here $$x^*$$ is the point in the interval which maximizes $$|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|$$. 

Technical jargon aside, if you could use this estimate to find the largest value of $$|x-1|$$ for which the remainder is less than the error tolerance we need, you'd have your interval.

The remainder theorem for Taylor polynomials states that the remainder between a function and it's n'th Taylor polynomial centred for x in some interval centred at a is 

$$R_n(x) \leq \frac{|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|}{(n+1)!}|x-a|^{n+1}$$

... where here $$x^*$$ is the point in the interval which maximizes $$|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|$$. 

Technical jargon aside, if you could use this estimate to find the largest value of $$|x-1|$$ for which the remainder is less than the error tolerance we need, you'd have your interval

The remainder theorem for Taylor polynomials states that the remainder between a function and it's n'th Taylor polynomial is 

$$R_n(x) \leq \frac{|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|}{(n+1)!}$$

Question:
WH3 Q3 part 1: Q3 part 1 asks for the upper error bound for the nth degree. Typically, Taylor error is calculated for a given degree.  Do we rely on the fact that the 0th degree polynomial would have the most error? Or do we somehow find an upper bound for the derivative (which is infinite if n isn't given?)?

Side note, I did parts b and c fine and got an exact error formula there. However, I don't feel like the closed form expression of Pn is supposed to be used for A.
Answer:
Taylor polynomials have a lot of moving parts, so let's restate the question quickly:

Consider $$f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}$$, and it's n'th Taylor polynomial centred at $$a=0$$,

$$P_n^a(x) = \sum_{i=0}^n \frac{f^{(i)}(a)}{i!}(x-a)^i$$

You have been given a theorem for estimating the error between $$f(x) - P_n^a(x)$$ which would be quite helpful in finding an upper bound for this error. This error will probably depend on which Taylor polynomial you use to estimate the original function (i.e. which $$n$$ you choose for the Taylor polynomials $$P_n^a(x)$$). All that needs to be done is find how the error depends on $$n$$.

Hope this helps!

Question:
WeBWork 8 Question 1:

Hello, can someone please tell me where I am going wrong with this question? The question is:

I got the first two right, but the last two parts are marked wrong. Here are my steps for the third part:

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{f''(c)}{2!}(x-c)^2$$

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{\frac{-1}{(-3+4)^2}}{2}(x+3)^2$$

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{-1}{2}(x+3)^2$$

This is what I have, but it's marking me wrong. Any help would be appreciated!
Answer:
They want the whole sum (like every previous term) in each block, so for example, number 3 would look like:

$$\displaystyle x+3+\frac{-1}{2}(x+3)^2$$

You seem to be only entering the very last term of your polynomial. $$p_0$$ and $$p_1$$ have one term only, and that is why they were OK. Try computing and entering the entire polynomial.

Question: Question 1 part 2 - use of undetermined constant coefficients (c1, c2, etc): Question 1 part 2 asks for a particular solution and a single solution to the homogenous system given information about the characteristic polynomial. In other words, we are finding the particular and complementary solutions. I just wanted to check if our final solutions are allowed to have undetermined coefficients (ie c1, c2, etc)? Are both the complementary and particular solutions allowed to have them?
Answer:
In part a), we show that if $$y_p(t) = A(t)e^{\alpha t}$$ is a particular solution to our differential equation, then we need to solve a different ODE for $$A(t)$$ such that

$$\frac{P''(\alpha)}{2} A''(t) + P'(\alpha) A'(t) + P(\alpha) A(t) = 1 $$

What does this mean exactly? Well, $$P$$ is the characteristic polynomial for the original mass spring system. $$P(\alpha)$$ and it's derivatives are just constants for the sake of the ODE since they don't depend on $$t$$. This means that this ODE describes the behaviour for $$A(t)$$. If we can find $$A(t)$$, then we know what our particular solution will be. 

Good luck!

In part a), we show that if $$y_p(t) = A(t)e^{\alpha t}$$ is a particular solution to our differential equation, then we need to solve a different ODE for $$A(t)$$ such that

$$\frac{P''(\alpha)}{2} A''(t) + P'(\alpha) A'(t) + P(\alpha) A(t) = 1 $$

Question:
E3 PCE convergence at endpoint: <md>PCE for module E3 reads:

> For example the geometric series  
>
> $$1+x+x^2+\cdots=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} x^n$$
>
> is convergent on (-1, 1).

For $$x=-1$$ this power series should look like $$1+(-1)+(-1)^2+(-1)^3+\cdots$$, which is effectively sum of $$1$$'s with oscillating signs, which at the end should be either $$0$$ or $$1$$ depending on the parity of $$n$$. This makes me think that the convergence interval should be $$[-1,1)$$. Please clarify if I am missing something.</md>
Answer:
We say that a series converges if it's sequence of partial sums converge. The partial sum for this series is 

$$S_k = \sum_{i=0}^k (-1)^i = 1 - 1 + 1 -1 + ... $$

You have correctly identified that if $$k$$ is even then $$S_k = 1$$ and if $$k$$ is odd then $$S_k = 0$$. Now let's take a step back and just think of $$S_k$$ as a members of a sequence which I will call $$b_k$$. 

$$b_k = \{S_k\}_0^{\inf} = \{1, 0, 1, 0, 1, ... \}$$

Does this sequence $$b_k$$ converge to some number? Hope this helps.

Question: WH3, Q1, part 2: What is meant by "single solution"? Is it referring to a solution without unknowns, a complementary solution, or something else?
Answer: A complementary solution is a term used for the general solution to the corresponding homogeneous ODE. A complementary solution is a family of solutions and has ALL the possible solutions to the homogeneous ODE. This question wants you to find a single solution in that general solution.

Question:
Lecture D3 question:

Sorry I forgot what my table group discussed during this lecture, but why must we take mu >= 0 here? I'm struggling to understand the arithmetic done on the bottom.
Answer:
The differential equation comes from Newton's second law (the case of rectilinear motion):

$$ma=F \Rightarrow mx''=-\mu x'-kx+f(t)$$

where $$k$$ is the spring constant and $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of resistance.

The negative sign in front of the term $$\mu x'$$ is necessary because we know that this force (a resistive force like friction or air resistance) opposes motion (given by $$x'$$) instead of helping. To maintain this relationship with motion, it is necessary to take $$\mu\ge0$$, otherwise the term becomes positive and loses its physical meaning (a force in the same direction of motion is not a resistive force).

Question:
WeBWorK 9, Problem 8:

I understand that we can solve for B using the sum of a geometric series, but how can we solve for A?
Answer:
As the question suggests, the infinite series A is in the form of a Taylor series -- this can be made more obvious by replacing $$5$$ with $$x$$: $$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n)!} = 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots$$ So if we can find the function to which the series converges, we can evaluate it at $$x=5$$ to find the value of the series. Hint: consider the Taylor series of the trigonometric functions. As the question suggests, the infinite series A is in the form of a Taylor series -- this can be made more obvious by replacing $$5$$ with $$x$$: $$\displaystyle 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots +\frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n)!}$$ So if we can find the function to which the series converges, we can evaluate it at $$x=5$$ to find the value of the series. Hint: consider the Taylor series of the trigonometric functions.

As the question suggests, the integer series A is in the form of a Taylor series -- this can be made more obvious by replacing $$5$$ with $$x$$:

$$\displaystyle 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots +\frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n!)}$$

So if we can find the function to which the series converges, we can evaluate it at $$x=5$$ to find the value of the series.

Question: Webwork 9 Problem 3: I tried and I still can't get the general form. I honestly have no more ideas. Any hints?
Answer:
What worked for me is that I chose an n0 first, then constructed my general form. I recommend choosing an n0 that we have seen often in examples from lectures and tutorials.

I would look at the relation between the powers of each numerator in the term, and how they relate to your chosen n0, whatever it may be. In this case, that would be 3,6,9,12...

The (x-6) is constant in each term, so it will likely be (x-6) raised to some exponent that is dependent on n. This will give you your numerator.

I would also look at the denominator as a product of two parts that depend on n, for example, it looks like your denominator is some power of an exponential with base 2 (2^0, 2^1, 2^2...), multiplied by a factorial that increases by 1 each term. This should help you write a general form for the denominator that is dependent on n, starting at your chosen n0.

Then combine the general forms of the numerator and denominator.

Question:
taylor series E3 slides question:

how did they know it approaches 0 only when x//(x-1)<1?
Answer:
There are three possibilities. Let $$ a= \frac{x}{1-x}$$ 

Case 1: $$a = 1$$
In this case $$a^n$$ = 1 regardless of the value of n.

Case 2: $$a > 1$$
In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ > $$a^n$$. i.e it is increasing and the limit will tend to infinity.

Case 3: $$a < 1$$
In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ < $$a^{n}$$. i.e each term is decreasing (eg. $$(0.5)^2$$ < $$(0.5)^{1})$$, and so the limit of this term as n--> $$\infty$$ will be 0.
There are three possibilities. Let $$ a= \frac{x}{x-1}$$ 

Case 1: $$a = 1$$
In this case $$a^n$$ = 1 regardless of the value of n.

Case 2: $$a > 1$$
In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ > $$a^n$$. i.e it is increasing and the limit will tend to infinity.

Case 3: $$a < 1$$
In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ < $$a^{n}$$. i.e each term is decreasing (eg. $$(0.5)^2$$ < $$(0.5)^{1})$$, and so the limit of this term as n--> $$\infty$$ will be 0.

Question:
WH3 Q2 Part (2) Limit:

Hello, I am attempting to take the following limit: $$\lim_{w\rightarrow 3}(\frac{cos(wt)}{9-w^2})$$. This is one of the terms I get from Part (1) of this question. I am unsure how to go about solving this limit.

Given that there is an unknown value t, for example, can you use L'Hopital here? Even though with direct substitution: $$\lim_{w\rightarrow 3}(\frac{cos(3t)}{0})$$ which is not $$\frac{0}{0}$$ but maybe $$t$$ results in a value that will make $$cos(3t) = 0$$. 

Just a bit lost here
Answer:
When you arrive at a limit of the form $$\lim\limits_{t\to 0}\frac{A}{t}$$ where $$A\in\mathbb{R}^*$$, you need to take limits on each side (i.e. $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^+}$$ and $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^-}$$).

EDIT : It may be easier to not use limit properties to split up the function. Two of the three terms in the function have the same denominator so you can easily turn the entire function into one rational function.

EDIT 2: Just use L'Hopitals rule to be safe. No need to split the limit, that causes unneccessary work.

When you arrive at a limit of the form $$\lim\limits_{t\to 0}\frac{A}{t}$$ where $$A\in\mathbb{R}^*$$, you need to take limits on each side (i.e. $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^+}$$ and $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^-}$$).

EDIT : It may be easier to not use limit properties to split up the function. Two of the three terms in the function have the same denominator so you can easily turn the entire function into one rational function.

When you arrive at a limit of the form $$\lim\limits_{t\to 0}\frac{A}{t}$$ where $$A\in\mathbb{R}^*$$, you need to take limits on each side (i.e. $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^+}$$ and $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^-}$$).

Question:
Series convergence question.: In PCE E2 (please correct me if I’m wrong) I think it states that if the partial sum of an infinite series converges, we know that the infinite series converges. 

Why is this true?
Answer:
This fact follows from the definition; an infinite sum is said to converge if $$\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}\sum_{n=1}^k a_n$$ (the sequence of partial sums). In other words, an "infinite sum" refers to this limit, not a "process" of repeating addition.

We use this definition because it's impossible (usually) to talk directly about infinity; as you can't reach it by counting normally, it is difficult to have any intuition about it. (I will expand this discussion later)

This fact follows from the definition; an infinite sum is said to converge if $$\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}\sum_{n=1}^k a_n$$ (the sequence of partial sums). In other words, an "infinite sum" refers to this limit, not a "process" of repeating addition.

Question:
Taylor Series Convergence and Divergence Question: Hi, I’m currently trying to learn why a Taylor series converges or diverges depending on its x-value and I’m having trouble doing so. 

My current understanding is that when looking at the taylor series of the form: IMG_6315_2024_03_14.jpeg

By altering x and a we are “changing” the infinite series to something that will either converge or diverge. 

I can’t help but wonder if there’s a better way of thinking about it. Is there? If so, what is it?
Answer:
To determine if a given Taylor series converges at a given x-value you need to determine if that x-value lies within the interval of convergence.

To determine the interval of convergence requires us to determine the radius of convergence using the ratio test. 

Computing the values for which $$L= lim_{n\to\infty} |\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}| < 1$$ where the series converges will directly lead to the determination of the radius of convergence.

Example)
Consider a given ratio test leads to the following: $$L=2 |4x-8|$$.

For the series for converge...
$$L<1$$ and so $$2 |4x-8| = 8 |x-2|< 1$$.

Thus, 
$$|x-2| < \frac{1}{8}$$

In this case the Radius of convergence, R = $$\frac{1}{8}$$

Now for the interval of convergence...
$$|x-2| < \frac{1}{8} \implies  \frac{-1}{8} < |x-2| < \frac{1}{8} $$

Thus the interval of convergence is the following....
$$\frac{15}{8} < x < \frac{17}{8} $$

Now the series converges for any x-value within the above interval of convergence. Note that at the endpoints we have to check for convergence or divergence separately.

Question: In class Non-homogeneous ODE question: For this question, can somebody tell me why the second graph's behavior corresponds to A instead of D? aren't they both decaying？
Answer:
Both A and D are oscillating functions due to the nature of having complex roots giving rise to the sin() and cos() in the solution. However the amplitude of A decreases exponentially, whereas the amplitude of D decreases linearly. 

As the general solution for the case with complex roots is of the form $$e^{\alpha t}$$[$$C_1cos(\beta t)+C_2sin(\beta t)$$], you can see the amplitude when $$\alpha < 0 $$ is decreasing exponentially, coming from the $$e^{\alpha t}$$ term. Thus the answer must be A.

Question:
Non-homogeneous ODE method of undetermined coefficient:

For these two problems in class, I understand why they are in the addition form, but if we have to solve one ODE like this, how are we supposed to come up with this kind of guess, or just memorize the pattern, for example, if it equals cos(x),we will guess Acos(x)+Bsin(x),and for te^t, we just guess Ae^t+Bte^t?
Answer:
Understanding the behavior of functions and their derivatives guides educated guesses when solving ODEs. Rather than memorizing patterns, analyzing characteristics such as derivatives helps determine appropriate forms for solutions, like ( Acos(x) + Bsin(x) ) for ( cos(x) ) or ( Ae^t + Bte^t ) for  te^t .

Question: Doubt on solution yielded by homogeneous linear ODE (with complex roots): When is such a function encountered while solving for homogenous linear odes with the characteristic equation yielding complex roots? I'd assume that the periodic nature of the interior function is a result of the c1cos(beta*t) + c2sin(beta*t). However, can the change of amplitude be attributed to e^sin or cos(alpha*t)? Looking forward to anyone's help on this!
Answer: You are correct. When solving homogeneous linear ODEs with complex roots in the characteristic equation, the solutions often involve functions with periodic behaviour  due to the presence of trigonometric functions like sine and cosine. The change in amplitude can indeed be attributed to terms involving exponential functions of the form e^{sin(alpha t)}or e^{cos(alpha t)} , which modulate the amplitudes of the trig functions.

Question:
Explanation for D3 Slides:

For the D3 slides lec 103, I'm struggling to understand what exactly is going on in this image. Could someone explain/lead me through it?
Answer:
They first find the expression for x(t) from the characteristic polynomial, and it's $$\cos((a / \sqrt{m}) t)$$. To see what happens when they increase the mass, they increase m in that formula and see that it slows down the oscillation. Then they give a kind of physical interpretation, the idea that mass increases inertia and that's why it happens.

Then they change a in a similar way, and see that it increases instead, and gives a physical interpretation too, a stiffer spring moves faster.

Question:
Radius of Convergence Inquiry:

When we solve for the radius of convergence for a given series, we use the ratio test: $$\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}$$. In LEC0102, we did this example:

Find the radius of convergence for the series $$\displaystyle\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^n}{n!}$$

When we do the ratio test: $$\displaystyle\frac{\frac{x\cdot x^n}{(n+1)!\cdot n}}{\frac{x^n}{n!}}$$ which becomes:

$$\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{x}{n+1}$$ which we say that the limit goes to zero. 

So in this case, do we say that the series converges for every value of $$x$$, and that the interval of convergence is $$(-\infty,\infty)$$?

Thanks!
Answer: Yes. Because regardless of what the value x is. It will =0 when the limit is taken. And since 0 < 1 we can say it converges for every value of x.

Question:
Approximating error using Taylor's Remainder Theorem: <md>I stumbled upon this question in 2021 Test 4:

![session-attachment-2024-03-16-201411.jpeg](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fllyhj9awro63lb%2F81859332ddbe241edf66f689a83a5fa52abf2ee986511b28de9a98adc0798e94%2Fsession-attachment-2024-03-16-201411.jpeg)

To approach this I decided to take $$p_2(t)$$ as the approximation and use $$R_2(t)$$ together with $$g'''(t)$$ to narrow down the error boundary. However I am not sure how to properly utilize the given boundaries for $$g'''(x)$$.

Since there are two distinct restrictions on $$g'''(x)$$, I am calculating two $$R_2(t)$$'s and see for which one I get smaller $$t^*$$ in $$p_2(t^*)+R_2(t^*)>0$$. Is my process correct?</md>
Answer:
it's there to help you find $$R(x)$$, since you need the maximum absolute value of the third derivative on the interval between the center and approximated point. since the absolute value reaches up to 6 between $$[1,t]$$, you should use that as the value for $$f(z)$$. if you check both though, you'll find the error of 6 is larger, so I guess it still works, but is not necessary.

Question:
tutorial 7 q1 b:

For this question, why is the error formula lesser than or equal to (12/3!)*t^3?? Doesn't the wording "stays below" mean the 3rd derivative should be less than 12?
Answer:
12 m/s² is an upper bound for the absolute value of the third derivative, but it is not the upper bound for the remainder. Therefore, because |s’’’(t)| < 12, then |s’’’(c)|t³ /3! < 12t³/3!

Hope this makes sense.

Question:
Tutorial 7 Q4:

For (a) why is A not the answer because from the graph it looks like the graph will be approaching zero?
For (c) I don't really understand the statement that "homogenous equation, can only have exponential increase/decrease" because if the characteristic polynomial has complex roots then the solution will be sinusoidal right?
Answer:
both are for the same reason. if a sinusoidal function from a second order ODE increases or decreases, it needs to do so exponentially in a way similar to $$e^x$$ since that's the "real part" that scales the rest of the function. when $$e^x$$ decreases, it decreases more at the beginning and approaches zero asymptotically. when it increases, it grows exponentially.

knowing this, we can see that A does not approach the x-axis asymptotically like $$e^{-kx}$$, and D increases linearly, which is impossible to create with $$e^{kx}$$.

knowing this, we can see that A does not approach the x-axis asymptotically like $$e^{-k}$$, and D increases linearly, which is impossible to created with $$e^k$$.

<md>There is a pretty clever geometric interpretation of this series that might be easier to visualize the series 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + ...
